nodes.bodyText:
A <dl></dl> is a "dictionary list".  It's defined as a series of <dt>/<dt> "terms" and <dd></dd> "definitions".
Its fine to have multiple definitions for a single term, but then they're considered 'alternative' definitions:  'multiple paragraphs forming part of the same value must all be given within the same dd element.'
I agree that most browsers don't make any distinction between multiple paragraphs within a value and multiple values.  Safari (my default browser) makes a visual distinction when doing default formatting, but doesn't make one with JMRI's CSS. John Plocher (@plocher)might have set that up intentionally.
There are places where it matters, though. We've recently seen one surface: a blind new user has been trying to work with JMRI via a screen reader.  He's uncovered several things in the program itself, most of which are now fixed.  But he's also sensitized me a bit to how we use HTML.  The screen reader is really good at working with standard HTML, but it's also quite literal:  It represents the mark up aspect of HTML quite specifically.
So I agree that it's not a reason to hold this PR. I'll merge it momentarily.  But it might be good to add to your every-growing list of things that could be improved in the documentation.
Thanks for your patience with this.
